summary: This document is a chain of emails from November 10, 2020, between U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) personnel and a law firm regarding a forwarded letter concerning a potential victim of Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell. The emails discuss the letter's routing, the law firm's aggressive representation of victims, and a query about whether images have been submitted to NCMEC for identification.

persons.name: Jennifer Freeman
persons.context: Sends the initial email with an annexed letter concerning a potential Epstein/Maxwell victim to Audrey Strauss.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.role: U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York (USANYS)
persons.context: Recipient of the initial email from Jennifer Freeman; the letter is forwarded to her office for review as it concerns a potential victim in a charged case.

persons.name: Joyanna Silberg
persons.context: Copied on the email from Jennifer Freeman to Audrey Strauss concerning the annexed victim letter.

connections.description: Freeman, an attorney, sends a confidential letter concerning a potential victim to U.S. Attorney Strauss for review and potential action.

events.title: Forwarding of Epstein Victim Letter
events.description: A letter from Marsh Law Firm concerning a potential Epstein/Maxwell victim is forwarded via email chain within the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York.

keyFacts: A law firm (Marsh Law Firm PLLC) sent a letter to the U.S. Attorney's Office concerning a potential victim of Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell.

The email chain indicates the Marsh Law Firm was known for being 'very aggressive in representing victims of child pornography' and that prior litigation with EOUSA (Executive Office for U.S. Attorneys) had occurred.
An internal query is raised about whether an HSI agent has submitted images to the National Center for Missing & Exploited Children (NCMEC) to identify them and the series they belong to.
The correspondence is marked as confidential and subject to attorney-client privilege, indicating sensitive legal communication.
